dt.t: was given a job {wi}commensurate{/wi} with her abilities
lived a life {wi}commensurate{/wi} with the early years of the republic

quotes.t: … athletes are rewarded {qword}commensurate{/qword} with their fame, not their intrinsic talent …

The last of the string family, the double bass, is the largest of all and must be played standing. Because it is seen in jazz bands, it has recently taken on an importance more nearly {qword}commensurate{/qword} with its size.

I find it interesting that the meanest life, the poorest existence, is attributed to God's will, but as human beings become more affluent, as their living standard and style begin to ascend the material scale, God descends the scale of responsibility at a {qword}commensurate{/qword} speed.

aq.source: {it}I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings{/it}

quotes.t: Because the effects of tobacco are slow—and iterative—and produce diseases that have other causes and explanations, often later in life, they seldom arouse fear {qword}commensurate{/qword} with their impact.

et: Late Latin {it}commensuratus{/it}, from Latin {it}com-{/it} + Late Latin {it}mensuratus{/it}, past participle of {it}mensurare{/it} to measure, from Latin {it}mensura{/it} measure {ma}{mat|measure|}{/ma}
shortdef: corresponding in size, extent, amount, or degree : proportionate
equal in measure or extent : coextensive
